qas.question: Do the roots and shoots need each other?
What do the roots get from the shoots?
What do the shoots get from the roots?
What are roots used for in beets and carrots?
What happens if a plant looses roots or its shoots?

context: The root system and the shoot system are <a0_0>interdependent<a0_0/> – the usually nonphotosynthetic root system depends on the shoot system for <a1_0>food<a1_0/>, and the usually photosynthetic shoot system depends on <a2_0>water and minerals<a2_0/> from the root system. Cells in each system are capable of creating cells of the other and producing adventitious shoots or roots. Stolons and tubers are examples of shoots that can grow roots. Roots that spread out close to the surface, such as those of willows, can produce shoots and ultimately new plants. In the event that one of the systems is lost, the other <a4_0>can often regrow it<a4_0/>. In fact it is possible to grow an entire plant from a single leaf, as is the case with Saintpaulia, or even a single cell – which can dedifferentiate into a callus (a mass of unspecialised cells) that can grow into a new plant. In vascular plants, the xylem and phloem are the conductive tissues that transport resources between shoots and roots. Roots are often adapted <a3_0>to store food<a3_0/> such as sugars or starch, as in sugar beets and carrots.
